sen.j: 高山 岩男（こうやま いわお、男性、1905年4月18日 - 1993年7月7日）は、日本の哲学者。
sen.e: Iwao KOYAMA (April 18, 1905 - July 7, 1993) was the Japanese philosopher.
Iwao KOYAMA (April 18, 1905 - July 7, 1993) was a Japanese philosopher.
Iwao KOYAMA (April 18, 1905 - July 7, 1993) was a Japanese philosopher.
He was born in Yamagata City, Yamagata Prefecture.
He was born in Yamagata City, Yamagata Prefecture.
He was born in Yamagata City, Yamagata Prefecture.

sen.j: 京都帝国大学哲学科卒。
sen.e: He graduated from the Department of Philosophy, Kyoto Imperial University.
He graduated from the Department of Philosophy, Kyoto Imperial University.
He graduated from the Department of Philosophy, Kyoto Imperial University.

sen.j: 西田幾多郎、波多野精一、田辺元、和辻哲郎ら、京都学派の全盛期にそこで哲学を学び、特に田辺から多大な影響を受ける。
sen.e: He studied philosophy when the Kyoto school was in the heyday with Kitaro NISHIDA, Seiichi HATANO, Hajime TANABE, and Tetsuro WATSUJI, and he had a great influence especially from Tanabe.
He studied philosophy during they heyday of the Kyoto School with Kitaro NISHIDA, Seiichi HATANO, Hajime TANABE, and Tetsuro WATSUJI, during which time he was greatly influenced particularly Tanabe.

He studied philosophy during the heyday of the Kyoto School with Kitaro NISHIDA, Seiichi HATANO, Hajime TANABE, and Tetsuro WATSUJI, during which time he was greatly influenced particularly by Tanabe.

sen.j: 卒業後、第三高等学校講師、1938年京都帝国大学文学部助教授、45年3月教授となるが、8月敗戦とともに退官。
sen.e: After graduation, he became the instructor of the Third High School, the assistant professor of Faculty of Letters, Kyoto Imperial University in 1938, and the professor in March, 1945, but he was retired at the time of the defeat in war in August.

After graduation, he became a lecturer at the Third High School before becoming an assistant professor of the Kyoto Imperial University Faculty of Letters in 1938 and being promoted to professor in March 1945, but he retired upon Japan's World War II defeat in August.

After graduation, he became a lecturer at the Third High School before becoming an assistant professor of the Kyoto Imperial University Faculty of Letters in 1938 and being promoted to professor in March 1945, but he retired upon Japan's World War II defeat in August.

sen.j: 息子は高山武彦日本製紙クレシア元社長。
sen.e: His son is Takehiko TAKAYAMA, the former president of Nippon Paper Crecia Co., Ltd..
His son is Takehiko TAKAYAMA, the former president of Nippon Paper Crecia Co., Ltd..
His son is Takehiko TAKAYAMA, the former president of Nippon Paper Crecia Co., Ltd..
Brief Personal History
Brief Personal History
Brief personal history

sen.j: 第二次世界大戦のさなか、1942年から翌年にかけて『中央公論』誌上で、「世界史的立場と日本」座談会（「世界史的立場と日本」昭和17年1月号、「東亜共栄圏の倫理性と歴史性」昭和17年4月号、「総力戦の哲学」昭和18年1月号）を京都大学の同僚、高坂正顕、西谷啓治、鈴木成高と行った。
sen.e: During the World War II, he had the symposium called 'World historical position and Japan' ('World historical position and Japan,' January issue in 1942, 'Morality and history of the Great East Asia Co-prosperity Sphere,' April issue in 1942, and 'Philosophy of all-out battle,' January issue in 1943) in the "Chuo Koron" with his colleagues at Kyoto Imperial University, such as Masaaki KOSAKA, Keiji NISHITANI, and Shigetaka SUZUKI, from 1942 to 1943.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: During the World War II, he had the symposium called 'World historical position and Japan' ('World historical position and Japan,' January issue in 1942, 'Morality and history of the Great East Asia Co-prosperity Sphere,' April issue in 1942, and 'Philosophy of all-out battle,' January issue in 1943) in the "Chuo Koron" with his colleagues at Kyoto Imperial University, such as Masaaki KOSAKA, Keiji NISHITANI, and Shigetaka SUZUKI, from 1942 to 1943.

From 1942 to 1943 during World War II, articles summarizing symposiums that Iwao KOYAMA held with Masaaki KOSAKA, Keiji NISHITANI, and Shigetaka SUZUKI (colleagues of his from Kyoto Imperial University) on topics such as ' The world's historical position and Japan' appeared in the magazine "Chuo Koron" ('The world's historical position and Japan' appeared in the January issue in 1942, 'The morality and history of the Great East Asia Co-prosperity Sphere' appeared in the April issue in 1942, and 'The philosophy of all-out battle' appeared in the January issue in 1943).
sen.cmt: ＮＣのコメントを受けて書き直しました。

sen.j: 戦争を大東亜共栄圏の建設という至上の理想、「近代の超克」のために止むを得ないものと肯定。
sen.e: He affirmed the war was imperative to 'overcome the modern age,' the supreme ideal to construct the Great East Asia Co-prosperity Sphere.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: They affirmed that the war was imperative in order to establish the supreme ideal of the Greater East Asia Co-Prosperity Sphere and to 'overcome the modern age'.
They affirmed that the war was imperative in order to establish the supreme ideal of the Greater East Asia Co-Prosperity Sphere and to 'overcome the modern age.'

sen.j: 特に海軍に対し、協力的な姿勢を示した。
sen.e: He indicated cooperative attitude especially to navy.
He displayed a cooperative stance, particularly toward the navy.
He displayed a cooperative stance, particularly toward the navy.

sen.j: 陸軍に協力を強要されるくらいなら、よりリベラルな海軍と手を結んで、という彼らの思惑もその背後にはあった。
sen.e: Their speculation that they'd rather deal with liberal navy than being forced to cooperate with an army was behind it.
Their speculation that they would rather deal with the more liberal navy than be forced into cooperating with the army was behind this.
Their speculation that they would rather deal with the more liberal navy than be forced into cooperating with the army was behind this.

sen.j: 戦後、公職を追放される。
sen.e: After the war, he was expelled from the official position.
After the war, he was expelled from his official position.
After the war, he was expelled from his official position.

sen.j: その間、浜名湖の畔に隠遁していた。
sen.e: During that time, he was retired by Hamana-ko Lake.
During that time, he went into retirement by Hamana-ko Lake.
During that time, he went into retirement by Hamana-ko Lake.

sen.j: その後、静岡新聞にコラムを執筆する傍ら、神奈川大学・日本大学・東海大学などで教職を歴任、最後は秋田経済法科大学の学長を務める。
sen.e: After that, while he was writing the column in The Shizuoka Shinbun (Newspaper), he taught at Kanagawa University, Nihon University, and Tokai University and served as the principal of Akita Keizaihoka University at last.

Following this, while writing a column for the Shizuoka Shinbun (newspaper), he taught at Kanagawa University, Nihon University and Tokai University before finally serving as the president of Akita Keizaihoka University.

Following this, while writing a column for the Shizuoka Shinbun (newspaper), he taught at Kanagawa University, Nihon University and Tokai University before finally serving as the president of Akita Keizaihoka University.

sen.j: 晩年は、東海大学に在籍した当時、京都大学の同窓の小原國芳の依頼で玉川大学大学院に係わるようになり、広義の哲学的人間学、教育学への関心を深めた。
sen.e: During his later life, he was involved in Graduate School of Tamagawa University by the request from Kuniyoshi OBARA, his colleague at Kyoto Imperial University, while he was enrolled in Tokai University, and he enhanced his interest in broad philosophical anthropology and pedagogy.

During his later life, he was involved in the Graduate School of Tamagawa University by the request of Kuniyoshi OBARA, his colleague at Kyoto Imperial University while he was enrolled in Tokai University, and he deepened his interest in broad philosophical anthropology and pedagogy.

During his later life, he was involved in the Graduate School of Tamagawa University by the request of Kuniyoshi OBARA, his colleague at Kyoto Imperial University while he was enrolled in Tokai University, and he deepened his interest in broad philosophical anthropology and pedagogy.

sen.j: その中心には、田辺元の「種の論理」に対して、自ら提唱した「呼応の論理」が据えられている。
sen.e: In the center of that, 'Logic of concord' that he proposed exists against Hajime TANABE's 'Logic of species.'
At the center of this was the 'logic of concord' that he proposed exists in opposition to Hajime TANABE's 'logic of species.'
At the center of this was the 'logic of concord' that he proposed exists in opposition to Hajime TANABE's 'logic of species.'

sen.j: 高坂正顕、西谷啓治、鈴木成高と共に「京都学派四天王」と呼ばれている。
sen.e: He is called 'The Four Heavenly Kings of the Kyoto school' with Masaaki KOSAKA, Keiji NISHITANI, and Shigetaka SUZUKI.
Iwao KOYAMA along with Masaaki KOSAKA, Keiji NISHITANI and Shigetaka SUZUKI are collectively referred to as 'The Four Heavenly Kings of the Kyoto School'.
Iwao KOYAMA along with Masaaki KOSAKA, Keiji NISHITANI and Shigetaka SUZUKI are collectively referred to as 'The Four Heavenly Kings of the Kyoto School.'
